awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A robotic system for removal of invasive plant species
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is to improve habitat for native plants and wildlife by removing invasive plants with a mobile robot. Worldwide invasion by non-native plant species is a primary concern in forest ecosystem health and biodiversity. Within the highly fragmented landscape of the Connecticut forest, two invasive plants significantly contribute to the degradation of habitat: Japanese barberry and multiflora rose. Current methods to eradicate them are time-consuming, expensive, and ultimately ineffective. This project presents a novel method of detecting and removing Japanese barberry and multiflora rose. Deep learning technology enables additional use with other invasive species, increasing the system's value throughout natural resource management. Additionally, once programmed, the robots will be easily operated, making them usable for a variety of personnel. This SBIR phase I project will advance current robot prototypes being tested for weed detection and removal. 

There is currently no mobile robot designed and programmed to remove understory invasive shrub species in a deciduous forest ecosystem. The technical challenges that will be addressed in building a feasible robot prototype include navigating over the unstructured terrain of the forest floor, developing a cutting attachment for the robotic arm, and creating a hybrid soft-rigid platform to withstand forest floor hazards while averting tree seedling damage. The proposed system will operate as follows: (1) an unpiloted aerial system (UAS, i.e., drone) flies over the canopy to capture images of the forest understory; (2) images are then labeled and converted to species location maps; and (3) utilizing these maps, a semi-autonomous mobile robot navigates to the invasive species locations for removal. The robots will be programmed for semi-automated missions monitored by an operator nearby at a safe distance to ensure worker safety.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Public Outcomes Report

BirdHabitatBot

 

Invasion by non-native plant species is rapidly destroying important native plant communities and threatening ecosystem health and biodiversity in deciduous forests around the world. The trees in deciduous forests lose their foliage at the end of every growing season, adding rich nutrients to the understory: the area between the forest canopy and ground where a wide variety of smaller trees, shrubs, and grasses provide food and shelter for a host of wildlife and birds. This complex ecosystem cleans the air we breathe, prevents soil erosion, provides timber, and sequesters carbon. Current invasive plant eradication methods are ineffective, costly, and harmful to people and the environment.

Now imagine a robot, or contingent of robots, programmed to identify invasives in a specific forest area, navigating their way across the challenging forest terrain, and eradicating the invasives without endangering native plants or using toxic herbicides. In this method, plant identification is done by flying drones over the canopy, location maps are created using deep learning and AI methods, and robots are programmed for semi-automated missions monitored by an operator at a safe distance. This report summarizes the outcomes of BirdHabitatBot?s Stage 1 research in developing what we are confident will be a new invasive management method that will be significantly cheaper, faster, safer, and more effective.

In this study we attempted to identify Multiflora Rose and Japanese Barberry, two of the most common invasive plants in the Northeast, with enough accuracy to create usable location maps. We completed 55 drone flights (3/18 ? 5/12/2022), capturing videos over 84 km of deciduous forest canopy in four tracts across Connecticut. We then labeled the images and converted them to species location maps using object detection, specifically, the deep learning model YOLO (You Only Look Once). YOLO uses bounding boxes to localize objects of interest. These bounding box coordinates can then be converted to a centralized latitude/longitude point for mapping.

The key outcome of this Phase 1 study is a 70% positive identification rate for Multiflora Rose and Japanese Barberry. Both invasives are very difficult to identify because of their specific features and leaf development, and this study marks the first time they have been identified with significant accuracy using drones and deep learning technology. We are confident we can increase the level of accuracy by adding more images to the datasets, which we will be doing this summer. Even before the robot prototype is built, tested, and ready to be deployed, the identification maps can be used by forest landowners or state agencies to monitor the density of invasive plant populations throughout the season and possibly from year to year. Marek has presented talks at 8 agencies and organizations in 2022-2023, and BirdHabitatBot?s website has had requests from 27 countries for more information on mapping and how to get involved.

Currently, we are continuing our work on building a robot prototype capable navigating over the unstructured terrain of the forest floor, developing a cutting attachment for the robotic arm, and creating a hybrid soft-rigid platform to withstand forest floor hazards while averting tree seedling damage. As of February 2023, Presco Engineering, specialists in product development and prototyping, are joining the team.

The Phase I grant gave us the opportunity to hire a master?s degree student as an intern and train her on flying the drone and processing imagery in the Agisoft Metashape software program. We will continue the collaboration with the University of Connecticut's remote sensing laboratory for Phase II.

We anticipate BirdHabitatBot will be first to market with its forestry robot designed to remove understory invasive shrub species, expanding the current robotics technology in precision agriculture, and creating a niche service for individuals or groups interested in protecting forest health. Once the prototype is developed, landowners can start tracking changes in the landscape ? restored populations of native plants, sightings of increased migratory bird populations and other wildlife. These data will be used to expand the use of remote sensing and robotics to track and monitor ecological patterns. Additional outcomes include: (1) Rebuilding the structure of native plant communities; (2) Fostering native seedling regeneration; and (3) Improving the overall productive capacity of the forest for birds and other wildlife.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/20/2023
Modified by: Nancy Marek
